The recent announcement that Donner and Blitzen have elected to take the early reindeer retirement package has triggered a good deal of concern about whether they will be replaced and about other restructuring decisions at the North Pole.
Streamlining was appropriate in view of the reality that the North Pole no longer dominates the season''s gift distribution business. Home shopping channels and mail order catalogues have diminished Santa''s market share
column2:
and he could not sit idly by and permit further erosion of the profit picture.

\n

The reindeer downsizing was made possible through the purchase of a late model Japanese sled for the CEO''s annual trip. Improved productivity from Dasher and Dancer
column3: who summered at the Harvard Business School
column4:
is anticipated and should take up the slack with no discernible loss of service. Reduction in reindeer will also lessen airborne environmental emissions for which the North Pole has been cited and received unfavorable press.

\n

I am pleased to inform you and yours that Rudolph''s role will not be disturbed. Tradition still counts for something at the North Pole. Management denies
column5: in the strongest possible language
column6: the earlier leak that Rudolph''s nose got that way not from the cold
column7: but from substance abuse. Calling Rudolph "a lush who was into the sauce and never did pull his share of the load" was an unfortunate comment
column8:
made by one of Santa''s helpers and taken out of context at a time of year when he is known to be under executive stress.

\n

As a further restructuring
column9: today''s global challenges require the North Pole to continue to look for better
column10: more competitive steps. Effective immediately
column11:
the following economy measures are to take place in the "Twelve Days of Christmas" subsidiary:

\n

The partridge will be retained
column12: but the pear tree never turned out to be the cash crop forecasted. It will be replaced by a plastic hanging plant
column13:
providing considerable savings in maintenance.

\n

The two turtle doves represent a redundancy that is simply not cost effective. In addition
column14:
their romance during working hours could not be condoned. The positions are therefore eliminated.

\n

The three French hens will remain intact. After all
column15:
everyone loves the French.

\n

The four calling birds were replaced by an automated voice mail system
column16: with a call waiting option. An analysis is underway to determine who the birds have been calling
column17:
how often and how long they talked.

\n

The five golden rings have been put on hold by the Board of Directors. Maintaining a portfolio based on one commodity could have negative implications for institutional investors. Diversification into other precious metals as well as a mix of T-Bills and high technology stocks appears to be in order.

\n

The six geese-a-laying constitute a luxury which can no longer be afforded. It has long been felt that the production rate of one egg per goose per day is an example of the decline in productivity. Three geese will be let go
column18:
and an upgrading in the selection procedure by personnel will assure management that from now on every goose it gets will be a good one.

\n

The seven swans-a-swimming is obviously a number chosen in better times. Their function is primarily decorative. Mechanical swans are on order. The current swans will be retrained to learn some new strokes and therefore enhance their outplacement.

\n

As you know
column19: the eight maids-a-milking concept has been under heavy scrutiny by the EEOC. A male/female balance in the workforce is being sought. The more militant maids consider this a dead-end job with no upward mobility. Automation of the process may permit the maids to try a-mending
column20:
a-mentoring or a-mulching.

\n

Nine ladies dancing has always been an odd number. This function will be phased out as these individuals grow older and can no longer do the steps.

\n

Ten lords-a-leaping is overkill. The high cost of lords plus the expense of international air travel prompted the compensation committee to suggest replacing this group with ten out-of-work congressmen. While leaping ability may be somewhat sacrificed
column21:
the savings are significant because we expect an oversupply of unemployed congressmen this year.

\n

Eleven pipers piping and twelve drummers drumming is a simple case of the band getting too big. A substitution with a string quartet
column22: a cutback on new music
column23:
and no uniforms will produce savings which will drop right down to the bottom line.

\n

We can expect a substantial reduction in assorted people
column24: fowl
column25: animals
column27: studies indicate that stretching deliveries over twelve days is inefficient. If we can drop ship in one day
column28:
service levels will be improved.

\n

Action is pending regarding the lawsuit filed by the attorneys'' association seeking expansion to include the legal profession ("thirteen lawyers-a-suing").

\n

Lastly
column29: it is not beyond consideration that deeper cuts may be necessary in the future to stay competitive. Should that happen
column30:
the Board will request management to scrutinize the Snow White Division to see if seven dwarfs is the right number.

Happy Holidays!
